Mitigating Data Injection Attacks on Federated Learning

TL;DR: Proposed method detects and mitigates false data injection attacks in federated learning systems.

Summary of “Mitigating Data Injection Attacks on Federated Learning”

Introduction

Data has become a crucial asset in various industries, emphasizing the need for privacy and security. Federated learning is a popular approach for training machine learning models collaboratively while preserving data privacy. However, federated learning is susceptible to various security threats, including data injection attacks, where malicious participants inject false data into the training process to manipulate the global model.

Problem Formulation

Federated Learning

  • Federated learning involves multiple agents refining model parameters using their private data to minimize an objective function using a gradient descent approach.
  • The agents exchange local model parameters with a coordinating node, and the goal is to minimize the objective function using a gradient descent approach.

Data Injection Attacks

  • Malicious agents inject false data into the training process to manipulate the global model, leading to suboptimal models.
  • Different attack schemes include label-flipping attacks, constant output attacks, and randomized attacks.

Attacker Detection and Avoidance

The coordinating agent uses a metric to compare updates received from edge agents and identifies malicious agents. A detection metric is proposed, and a low-complexity metric is computed over time to localize the attacker. If an agent is suspected to be malicious, its updates are ignored for a certain period. The proposed detection method allows for continuous operation, even during the convergence time of the joint model.

Simulations

Example 1: Constant-Output Attack

  • The simulation shows the impact of a constant-output attack by a single attacker on various network sizes with and without detection.
  • The proposed detection scheme successfully detects the attacker before it affects the network, allowing convergence of the model to a good model.

Example 2: Label-Flip Attack

  • The simulation illustrates the impact of a label-flip attack by a single attacker with and without detection.
  • With the proposed detection, the attacker is identified, and the average classification error is mitigated.

Conclusions

The paper presents a robust federated learning algorithm that can operate in the presence of data injection attacks. It provides conditions for identifying malicious agents and demonstrates the performance of the proposed technique on various data injection attacks.

The paper addresses the significant challenge of mitigating data injection attacks on federated learning systems. It proposes a novel technique for detecting and mitigating such attacks, showcasing its effectiveness through simulations. The proposed detection and mitigation methods offer a promising approach to safeguard federated learning systems from malicious activities. The paper concludes by emphasizing the robustness and performance of the proposed technique in addressing data injection attacks.
